articles.headline: Viacom’s Weak Results Pile On More Bad News for TV Industry
articles.snippet: Viacom shares were down as much as 22 percent as a startling slump in major media stocks continued on Thursday.
articles.abstract: Viacom shares were down as much as 22 percent as a startling slump in major media stocks continued on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is no more than a coincidence that Viacom announced weak earnings and suffered a sharp plunge in its stock on the same day that one of its biggest stars, Jon Stewart, exited the stage.

articles.headline: As China Reduces Local Spending, Cities Woo Private Investors
articles.snippet: Hundreds of cities across China are turning to deep-pocketed private investors to help foot the bill for public infrastructure and services.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of cities across China are turning to deep-pocketed private investors to help foot the bill for public infrastructure and services.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The wide new boulevards that cut across parts of Weifang in eastern China are largely free of traffic, a quiet reminder of the coastal city’s big ambitions.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough and Cao Li

articles.headline: King Coal, Long Besieged, Is Deposed by the Market
articles.snippet: In a few short years, market forces have accomplished what environmentalists struggled to do for decades: curtail America’s coal consumption.
articles.abstract: In a few short years, market forces have accomplished what environmentalists struggled to do for decades: curtail America’s coal consumption.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April 2005, President George W. Bush hailed “clean coal” as a key to “greater energy independence,” pledging $2 billion in research funds that promised a new golden age for America’s most abundant energy resource.

articles.headline: Soul-Searching in Israel After Bias Attacks on Gays and Arabs
articles.snippet: After two attacks that underscored Israel’s conflict with the Palestinians and its internal struggle, there has been outrage, blame and backlash.
articles.abstract: After two attacks that underscored Israel’s conflict with the Palestinians and its internal struggle, there has been outrage, blame and backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — On one edge of the Zion Square gathering, an Orthodox yeshiva student was in heated debate with a secular couple over the hierarchy of sin. On the other, young men wearing skullcaps rocked back and forth, reciting the evening prayer. In between, people sat cross-legged on the cobblestones amid an array of memorial candles and banners decrying violence, promoting love, demanding change.

articles.headline: Why Putting a Number to C.E.O. Pay Might Bring Change
articles.snippet: A new rule requiring a company to give the ratio of the top executive’s pay to worker pay will produce an easily grasped and perhaps shocking number.
articles.abstract: A new rule requiring a company to give the ratio of the top executive’s pay to worker pay will produce an easily grasped and perhaps shocking number.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a confounding truth about outsize executive pay — all past attempts to rein it in have failed.

articles.headline: Ackman Bets on Mondelez Going on Sale
articles.snippet: The emergence of Pershing Square Capital Management as a major investor in Mondelez highlights the widespread belief that opportunities for deals abound in the food sector.
articles.abstract: The emergence of Pershing Square Capital Management as a major investor in Mondelez highlights the widespread belief that opportunities for deals abound in the food sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: By putting $5.5 billion into Mondelez International, a hedge fund billionaire is wagering that the company, which makes Oreos, Cadbury chocolates and Trident gum, could be prodded into selling itself.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: The Never-Ending Lawsuit Against 2 Former A.I.G. Executives
articles.snippet: A still-going suit brought by Eliot Spitzer against Maurice Greenberg and another executive in 2005 shows the effectiveness of certain tactics in prolonging proceedings.
articles.abstract: A still-going suit brought by Eliot Spitzer against Maurice Greenberg and another executive in 2005 shows the effectiveness of certain tactics in prolonging proceedings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charles Dickens invented the interminable estate dispute Jarndyce v. Jarndyce for “Bleak House,” his 1853 novel. In real life, the Federal Trade Commission once took 16 years to force Carter’s Little Liver Pills to drop the word “Liver.” And antitrust regulators spent 13 years on a case against IBM before the Reagan administration dropped it abruptly.

articles.headline: Chuck Schumer Opposes Iran Nuclear Deal, Shaking Democratic Firewall
articles.snippet: The decision by Senator Chuck Schumer, an influential Jewish voice in Congress, paved the way for other Democrats on the fence to join critics of the deal.
articles.abstract: The decision by Senator Chuck Schumer, an influential Jewish voice in Congress, paved the way for other Democrats on the fence to join critics of the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Chuck Schumer, the most influential Jewish voice in Congress, said Thursday night that he would oppose President Obama’s deal to limit Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Rivals Jab at Donald Trump as Republican Debate Becomes Testy
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump was put on the defensive from the start of the debate, not only by his rivals but by the debate moderators from Fox News.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump was put on the defensive from the start of the debate, not only by his rivals but by the debate moderators from Fox News.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shedding any pretense of civility and party unity, Donald J. Trump overwhelmed the first Republican presidential debate on Thursday night by ripping into his rivals and the moderators alike, but also drew fire from Jeb Bush and others who are seeking to stop his breathtaking surge.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Donald Trump Steals the Show, Mixing Politics and Pizazz
articles.snippet: From the opening moments, when he flashed a grin and a victory sign at the crowd, Mr. Trump remained his irrepressible self: aggrandizing, unapologetic and cutting.
articles.abstract: From the opening moments, when he flashed a grin and a victory sign at the crowd, Mr. Trump remained his irrepressible self: aggrandizing, unapologetic and cutting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was outrageous. He was demeaning. He was even somewhat menacing, warning a female moderator that he could turn on her at any moment.

articles.headline: Job Growth Steady in July, Possibly Easing Path for Fed Action
articles.snippet: With the central bank assessing the labor market as it considers raising rates, the economy added 215,000 jobs and unemployment stayed at 5.3 percent.
articles.abstract: With the central bank assessing the labor market as it considers raising rates, the economy added 215,000 jobs and unemployment stayed at 5.3 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy delivered pretty much what was expected last month in terms of hiring, giving the Federal Reserve one more piece of evidence that conditions are strong enough to support an increase in the interest rate.

articles.headline: Petrobras Oil Scandal Leaves Brazilians Lamenting a Lost Dream
articles.snippet: A far-reaching investigation into corruption at the state oil company has destabilized the government, damaged the economy and wounded national pride.
articles.abstract: A far-reaching investigation into corruption at the state oil company has destabilized the government, damaged the economy and wounded national pride.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alberto Youssef, a convicted money launderer and former bon vivant, sat in a Brazilian jail cell in March of last year, getting ready to tell his lawyers a story. It was about an elaborate bribery scheme involving Petrobras, the government-controlled oil giant. He opened with a dire prediction.

articles.headline: How to Approach the Generation Gap in the Workplace
articles.snippet: Readers share their advice about navigating the workplace in an era when millennials are hiring and managing older employees.
articles.abstract: Readers share their advice about navigating the workplace in an era when millennials are hiring and managing older employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: A generation gap is widening in the workplace. As baby boomers (ages 51 to 69 or so) express reluctance about retiring, so-called millennials (roughly ages 18 to 34) have become the single largest demographic in the American labor force. Because of this, more older workers have found themselves being hired and managed by people much younger than they are.
